channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Ukraine troops retreat from key town
item.description: Ukraine's president says his forces are making an "organised" withdrawal from the strategic town of Debaltseve, under siege by rebel forces.

item.title: Swiss raid HSBC's Geneva office
item.description: Swiss prosecutors search offices of the Geneva subsidiary of HSBC bank in an inquiry into alleged money-laundering.

item.title: Further fall in UK unemployment
item.description: The number of people out of work in the UK fell by 97,000 to 1.86 million in the three months to December, official figures show.

item.title: UK police examine Chelsea fans video
item.description: UK officers are to examine footage appearing to show Chelsea football fans stopping a black man from boarding a Paris train, the Met Police says.

item.title: Energy customers 'miss big savings'
item.description: Dual-fuel customers of the big energy firms have missed big savings by not switching suppliers, early evidence from a competition inquiry suggests.

item.title: Greece will request loan extension
item.description: Greece will request a six-month extension of its loan agreement on Wednesday, a Greek government official confirms.

item.title: NHS misses a year of cancer targets
item.description: The NHS in England has repeatedly missed a key target for rapidly treating cancer patients, official figures for 2014 show.

item.title: Rise in Romania and Bulgaria workers
item.description: The number of Romanians and Bulgarians working in the UK has risen by almost 15% in the past 12 months, official figures show.

item.title: Oborne calls for Telegraph inquiry
item.description: The Daily Telegraph's former chief political commentator Peter Oborne calls for an independent review of the newspaper's guidelines over its HSBC tax scandal coverage.

item.title: Jury out in soldier terror plot trial
item.description: The jury in the trial of a teenager accused of planning to behead a British soldier retires to consider its verdict.

item.title: Fire breaks out on EastEnders set
item.description: A fire breaks out on the set of EastEnders a few hours after the soap staged a live broadcast to mark its 30th anniversary.

item.title: Clarke named Ryder Cup captain
item.description: Northern Ireland's Darren Clarke is named Europe's Ryder Cup captain for the 2016 tournament at Hazeltine, United States.

item.title: How political polls shape opinion
item.description: The BBC's David Cowling looks at the rising influence of political polls on British public opinion.

item.title: Argentina's leader faces rocky times
item.description: Why Argentine President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner has lost support over her handling of the probe into the death of prosecutor Alberto Nisman.

item.title: Hubble's star refuses to fade
item.description: Scientists say they have every hope that the Hubble Space Telescope will keep working for at least another five years, perhaps more.

item.title: Is the Nato military alliance broken?
item.description: As the Baltic states look on uneasily at Ukraine’s latest fragile ceasefire, what has the conflict revealed about the West’s military alliance Nato?

item.title: Viewpoint: Denmark prepared for attack but nowhere is safe
item.description: Denmark has long prepared for a possible attack but the Copenhagen shootings still came as a shock, says former security chief Hans Jorgen Bonnichsen.

item.title: What if Greece quits the euro?
item.description: Neither the Greek government nor its eurozone partners want to see a "Grexit". But if they cannot agree a way forward it could come to that - so what might the consequences be?

item.title: Egypt and the threat of IS in Libya
item.description: Precise information about Egypt's role in Libya is hard to come by, says Jawad Iqbal

item.title: Brian the horse fails police trial
item.description: A horse called Brian, whose proposed name change caused anger among his namesakes, fails his police trial.

item.title: Limpet teeth set new strength record
item.description: Engineers find that limpets' tiny teeth are made of the strongest biological material ever tested.

item.title: Ohuruogu criticises IAAF chief
item.description: Christine Ohuruogu criticises the head of world athletics for saying the sport faces a "crisis" over doping allegations.

item.title: Murray's motivational notes revealed
item.description: Dutch sports journalist Wilfred Genee revealed British number one Andy Murray's motivational messages at the Rotterdam Open.

item.title: Wolff to drive Williams in testing
item.description: Susie Wolff will drive the new Williams FW37 on the first day of testing at the Circuit de Catalunya in Barcelona on Thursday.

item.title: Rooney sorry for 'dive' - PNE keeper
item.description: Preston goalkeeper Thorsten Stuckmann says Manchester United's Wayne Rooney apologised for his controversial penalty.

item.title: Afghanistan lose on World Cup debut
item.description: Afghanistan's debut World Cup match ends in defeat as Bangladesh are victorious by 105 runs in Canberra.

item.title: Rolls-Royce announces SUV plan
item.description: Luxury carmaker Rolls-Royce says it is to add a sports utility vehicle (SUV), or "high-bodied car", to its line-up of models.

item.title: France PM pushes key reforms through
item.description: French PM Manuel Valls uses an emergency procedure to push through key labour market reforms without a vote by MPs.

item.title: Ex-Labour NEC chairwoman backs UKIP
item.description: Harriet Yeo, a former senior Labour official, says she has left the party to support UKIP at the general election because she is "disillusioned" with Labour's stance on Europe.

item.title: Cuts 'put councils on cliff-edge'
item.description: Public services like adult social care could "collapse" unless councils get new funding powers, the Independent Commission on Local Government Finance says.

item.title: Call to snoop on antibiotic scripts
item.description: Doctors should snoop on their colleagues to ensure they are not prescribing too many antibiotics, the NHS in England suggests.

item.title: 12-hour A&E visits worst on record
item.description: The number of people spending more than 12 hours in accident and emergency in Wales is at its highest since records began in 2012.

item.title: Creativity 'squeezed out of schools'
item.description: Creativity and the arts are being squeezed out of schools, a report says.

item.title: How teacher brains detect confusion
item.description: A study has shed new light on the signals in the brain that warn teachers when their pupils have not understood them.

item.title: Malware on menu on Jamie Oliver site
item.description: The celebrity chef's site suffered a "malware problem" after being hacked, but has since been fixed, according to a Jamie Oliver Group spokesman.

item.title: Google faces Android probe in Russia
item.description: Search company Yandex files a complaint with Russia's competition watchdog about the restrictions Google places on Android phone-makers.

item.title: Alien star invaded the Solar System
item.description: An alien star passed through our Solar System just 70,000 years ago, astronomers have announced.

item.title: Everest climbing route to be changed
item.description: The route used by mountaineers to scale Mount Everest is to be changed for 2015, following last year's avalanche that killed 16.

item.title: Oliver rules out Daily Show return
item.description: HBO commissions two more series of Last Week Tonight With John Oliver, quashing rumours that he may replace Jon Stewart on The Daily Show.

item.title: Marigold sequel gets royal approval
item.description: The Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall join Dame Judi Dench on the orange carpet at the premiere of The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel.

item.title: Nutella recipes for hardcore fans
item.description: Not everyone eats Nutella on bread - some like it with chicken and garlic sauce.

item.title: What would happen if prices started going down?
item.description: Britain is heading for its first period of falling prices since 1989.

item.title: Boy died after abuse case 'failings'
item.description: A boy died from a severe head injury after authorities failed to act while he suffered years of abuse, a serious case review finds.

item.title: Cat litter used to stem store flood
item.description: A supermarket is forced to close after thousands of gallons of water from a burst main swamp the car park.

item.title: Emails contradict police claims
item.description: Police Scotland was not forced to release "inaccurate" stop-search data, according to new evidence released by the Information Commissioner.

item.title: Accused 'may have killed' dog walker
item.description: A man accused of murdering a dog walker told his mother he did not know if he killed her, a court hears.

item.title: Derry bomb was 'mortar type device'
item.description: A bomb found during a security alert in a housing estate in Londonderry is believed to have been a "mortar type device"

item.title: NI unemployment continuing to fall
item.description: The number of people claiming unemployment benefit in Northern Ireland fell by 1700 in January and now stands at just over 48,000.

item.title: Police 'not sure' boy is in river
item.description: Police say they are not "100% sure" a missing 11-year-old boy is in a river where they have been searching.

item.title: Controversial council plans in doubt
item.description: Opposition groups are preparing an alternative to Cardiff council's controversial budget plan ahead of next week's vote.

item.title: Army kills '300 Boko Haram fighters'
item.description: More than 300 Boko Haram fighters are killed during a military land and air operation in north-east Borno State, the Nigerian army says.

item.title: Tanzanian albino boy found mutilated
item.description: The body of an albino boy who went missing on Sunday is found in Tanzania with his limbs hacked off in what appears to be a witchcraft killing.

item.title: Afghan civilian deaths rise sharply
item.description: The number of civilian casualties of the conflict in Afghanistan increased by over 22% last year, latest UN figures say.

item.title: Lunar New Year celebrations begin
item.description: Countries across Asia begin Lunar New Year celebrations to welcome the year of the sheep, with tens of millions of people on the move in China.

item.title: Danish agents were warned on gunman
item.description: Denmark's intelligence agency says it was warned that Copenhagen gunman Omar El-Hussein was at risk of radicalisation before he killed two people.

item.title: Acquit Strauss-Kahn, says prosecutor
item.description: The former head of the IMF, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, should be acquitted of pimping charges due to insufficient evidence, says French prosecutor.

item.title: Mexico tackles pipeline fuel thefts
item.description: Mexico's state-owned oil company Pemex announces it will stop shipping ready-to-use petrol and diesel through its pipelines as fuel thefts soar.

item.title: Storms hit 1,500 Argentine homes
item.description: At least 1,500 houses were damaged as deadly storms hit the northern Argentine province of Cordoba, authorities say.

item.title: Syria 'agrees to halt Aleppo raids'
item.description: Syria's government is prepared to halt aerial attacks on Aleppo for six weeks as part of a local ceasefire plan, UN envoy Staffan de Mistura says.

item.title: Iran urged to halt execution of Kurd
item.description: Human rights groups urge Iran to halt the planned execution of an Iranian-Kurdish man for offences he is alleged to have committed when he was 17.

item.title: Obama: 'Law on our side' on migrants
item.description: President Barack Obama has hit back at a ruling in Texas that brought to a halt his radical immigration plan.

item.title: US hosts anti-extremism conference
item.description: The US opens a three-day conference on countering worldwide and domestic extremism, after a spate of recent terror attacks.

item.title: Day in pictures: 17 February 2015
item.description: Images from around the world: 17 February

item.title: Natural beauty captured in winning images
item.description: Winning garden images from across the world

item.title: Day in pictures: 16 February 2015
item.description: Images from around the world: 16 February

item.title: In pictures: Rio samba schools fight for title
item.description: Carnival battle in Rio

item.title: Week in pictures: 7-13 February 2015
item.description: Photos from around the world: 7-13 February

item.title: Day in pictures: 13 February 2015
item.description: Images from around the world: 13 February

item.title: World Press Photo of the Year
item.description: Picture of a gay couple in Russia wins first prize

item.title: Day in pictures: 12 February 2015
item.description: Images from around the world: 12 February

item.title: VIDEO: Home Affairs Committee
item.description: MPs take evidence from the new head of an inquiry into allegations of historic child abuse.

item.title: VIDEO: Video of Chelsea fans sparks outrage
item.description: UK police are examining footage appearing to show Chelsea football fans stopping a black man from boarding a Paris train.

item.title: VIDEO: Marathon runner crawls to finish line
item.description: A Kenyan marathon runner has crawled to the finish line after collapsing 50 metres from the end of the race in Austin, Texas.

item.title: VIDEO: How Italy copes with migrant influx
item.description: The BBC's Tom Burridge reports from the Italian island of Lampedusa, where authorities are struggling to cope with a huge influx of new migrants.

item.title: VIDEO: Relief for Ukraine troops heading home
item.description: The Ukrainian president says his forces are making an "organised" withdrawal from the embattled town of Debaltseve.

item.title: VIDEO: Is Cristina Argentina's new Evita?
item.description: Wyre Davies considers the country's interest in Argentina's president, Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner, as she faces the biggest challenge of her political career.

item.title: VIDEO: Records crash as US freeze continues
item.description: As cold and snowy weather continues to affect the US, part of Niagara Falls has frozen over.

item.title: VIDEO: Are looted antiquities funding IS?
item.description: A BBC investigation has gathered evidence of how looted antiquities are being smuggled from Syrian territory controlled by Islamic State militants.

item.title: VIDEO: On red carpet with Best Exotic stars
item.description: Dame Judi Dench and Celia Imrie at the Royal Gala premiere of the Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel

item.title: Creating Cold
item.description: The men who made the world a cooler place to live

item.title: When were PMs banned from driving?
item.description: When were PMs banned from getting behind the wheel?

item.title: What exactly is 'game theory'?
item.description: What is it and why does it matter so much?

item.title: VIDEO: Photographing women and war
item.description: The war photographer who goes where others can't

item.title: VIDEO: How can art help mental health?
item.description: Psychiatric hospital's art archives opened up

item.title: What the stars see on the red carpet
item.description: Take a trip down the Oscars' red carpet

item.title: Can Lithuania turn brain drain into brain gain?
item.description: Can Lithuania reverse loss of young and talented?

item.title: VIDEO: Can this light make you high?
item.description: Can this beam create a state of incredible relaxation?

item.title: Boycotting Bali over the death sentence
item.description: Death sentence for foreigners triggers social media spat

item.title: Top bosses on how to get things done
item.description: Top bosses share their secrets on how to get things done
